description.narrative:
Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights (SRHR) constitute a fundamental part of the overall attainment of human rights. Sweden has a long tradition of support to SRHR globally and in Uganda, where the ability to freely and safely exercise reproductive and sexual rights remains challenged.
Young people have special SRHR needs and their access – or lack hereof – to quality SRHR services has a key impact on their opportunities in life. Teenage pregnancies, early marriages, unsafe abortions, sexual and gender based violence, drug and substance abuse and sexually transmitted diseases including HIV all impact on the sexual and reproductive health of young people.
The Contribution responds to result area 3.2 (Improved access to sexual and reproductive health and rights for women and men, girls and boys) in the 2014-2018 Result Strategy for Sweden's International Development Cooperation with Uganda.
Naguru Teenage Information and Health Centre (NTIHC) has - with support from Sweden – provided youth friendly SRHR services for the past 15 years. NTIHC has developed into a centre of excellence, in Uganda and in the region, and has built a considerable expertise in adolescent SRHR (ASRHR). NTIHC is one of the few organisations in the country offering quality ASRHR services and it fills an important gap in the overall SRHR platform in Uganda.
The Embassy of Sweden in Uganda is supporting NTIHC’s 2015-2020 Strategic Plan with a total of 38.2 M SEK (84% of the Strategic Plan budget). The Strategic Plan redirects the previous focus from mainly service delivery to a stronger emphasis on best practice and advocacy.
Through the Contribution; NTIHC will receive technical support by RFSU through the framework agreement with Indevelop with the aim to 1) improve quality ASRHR service delivery, 2) strengthen advocacy capacity and 3) provide management support. The support will be provided over a period of 14 months and specific attention will be devoted to build NTIHC’s capacity to implement the new Strategic Plan and to increase NTIHC’s capacity for resource mobilization in order to reduce dependence on Swedish support. The budget for the technical support amounts to SEK 1 324 800.
RFSU also provided technical support in 2014-2015. Through the previous support, NTIHC was supported to develop its new Strategic Plan, to strengthen capacity for quality service delivery and to build management capacity.
NTIHC has repeatedly expressed that the support provided by InDevelop/RFSU is effective in strengthening the capacity of NTIHC to deliver its Strategic Plan.
Indevelop/RFSU on their side has provided the embassy with brief quarterly reports in writing on implementation progress as well as a more comprehensive end of support report. In addition, Indevelop / RFSU has met with the embassy to discuss the support.

Sexuell och Reproduktiv Hälsa och Rättigheter (SRHR) är en väsentlig del i arbetet med att uppnå mänskliga rättigheter. Sverige har en lång tradition av att stödja SRHR globalt samt i Uganda där möjligheten att fritt och säkert utöva reproduktiva och sexuella rättigheter fortfarande är en stor utmaning.
Ungdomar har speciella behov av SRHR och deras tillgång - eller saknaden av - kvalitativa SRHR tjänster spelar en viktig roll vad gäller deras livschanser. Tonårsgraviditeter, tidiga giftemål, osäkra aborter, sexuellt och genderbaserat våld, drogmissbruk och sexuellt överförbara sjukdomar inklusive HIV, har alla en inverkan på sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa för ungdomar.
Insatsen bidrar till uppfyllelsen av resultatområde 3.2 (Sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och rättigheter tillgodoses i större utsträckning för kvinnor, män, flickor och pojkar) i Sveriges resultatstrategi för utvecklingssamarbetet i Uganda 2014-2018.
Naguru Teenage Information and Health Centre (NTIHC) har - genom stöd från Sverige - tillhandahållit SRHR tjänster för ungdomar under de senaste 15 åren. NTIHC har utvecklats till ett framstående centrum i Uganda och i regionen. De har byggt upp en anmärkningsbar expertis inom SRHR för tonåringar. NTIHC är en av få organisation i Uganda som erbjuder kvalitativa SRHR tjänster för tonåringar och spelar en viktig roll i det övergripande SRHR arbetet i landet.
Sveriges Ambassad i Uganda stödjer, genom en annan insats, NTIHC:s 2015-2020 Strategiska plan med en total budget på 38.2 MSEK (84% av den Strategiska planens totala budget). Den Strategiska planen har i denna fas en starkare betoning på praxis och påverkansarbete till skillnad från förra fasen där tjänster var i fokus.
Genom denna insats kommer NTIHC att få tekniskt stöd från RFSU genom ett ramavtal med Indevelop, stödet har följande syften: 1. Förbättra kvalitén av SRHR tjänster för tonåringar 2. Stärka påverkansarbetet och 3. Ge stöd till ledningen. Stödet kommer att pågå under 14 månader och ett speciellt fokus kommer vara att stödja NTIHC:s kapacitet att implementera den nya Strategiska planen och att öka NTIHC:s kapacitet att mobilisera resurser för att minska beroendet av det svenska stödet. Budgeten för teknisk support är 1 324 800 SEK.
RFSU gav även teknisk support 2014-2015. Genom det tidigare stödet så stöttades NTIHC i att utveckla deras nya Strategiska plan, stärka kapaciteten för kvalitativa tjänster och att bygga kapacitet hos ledningen.
NTIHC har i återkommande fall uttryckt att stödet från InDevelop/RFSU är effektivt vad gäller deras kapacitetsstärkande av NTIHC och deras arbete med den Strategiska Planen.
Indevelop/RFSU har lämnat in både kvartalsenliga rapporter till Ambassaden där de beskrivit framsteg med implementeringen samt en mer fördjupad slutrapport. Utöver detta har Indevelop/RFSU haft möten med Ambassaden för att diskutera stödet.

participating-org.narrative: Naguru Teenage Information and Health Centre

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: This was a technical support through RFSU to Naguru Teenage Information & Health Center (NTIHC). Overall the support went according to plan and ended April 2017. The final report submitted by RFSU is explaining the activities and outcomes of the support period, March 2016 - April 2017. SRHR support: Two workshops for all NTIHC staff took place focusing on rights that are central to the clinics everyday work. One follow up visit of the support was also included under this component. NTIHC assess themselves to have gotten an increased understanding of SRHR, HR and RBA, and stated increased interest among both staff and senior management to take the work forward. There are still some gaps in knowledge, according to RFSU, especially on how to communicate to young people on perceived "sensitive issues" such as homosexuality, abortion, rape/consent and masturbation. Advocacy support: NTIHC has worked with a Ugandan consultant (Daudi Talima) contracted by RFSU. Support under this component was from October 2016-February 2017. The consultant provided capacity building training to the NTIHC advocacy team, but advocacy training was also included during one of the SRHR workshops for all staff. The third planned sub-component of advocacy support – capacity building for the monitoring and evaluation of advocacy work – did not take place. This decision, agreed in consultation with NTIHC, was taken partly because NTIHC was not yet ready to tackle these more advanced issues, but also because of the planned partner organisation for this activity – the Maternal Health Project – experienced organizational problems and withdrawal of SE funding. Management support: NTIHC has worked together with a consultant (Dr. Tim Lee) contracted by RFSU. The management team was given tailor-made support based on their stated needs and their ability to implement/manage the change process underway. Meetings and workshops were held with senior staff to review progress on matters in regards to the strategic plan, organizational assessment, audit of last agreement, new M&E arrangements, risk analysis/mitigation and organizational restructuring. As well as capacity building and strategizing documentation practices, technical support, partnership and resource mobilization. Meetings and workshops were held to build capacity of senior managers in good governance and organizational change and to prepare for annual report. One workshop was held with the Board to review governance arrangements and problem-solve the way forward. Distance support was also given in form of encouragement and technical support in ongoing processes in regards to governance and management.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
